posts.text:
Google's leaked documents confirmed it.

They use a secret metric called siteAuthority to determine who to trust.

The sites dominating search in 2025 and beyond aren't chasing keywords. They're owning entire topics.

7-step framework for building topical authority:

1. Define your core topic domain

Pick a niche you can actually dominate. "Email marketing" is too broad. "Email marketing for SaaS companies" works. Most people fail here by going too wide.

2. Uncover your entire topic universe

Map every subtopic and user question. Use Reddit, Quora, People Also Ask, competitor analysis. You need 1,000s of keywords, not 20.

3. Group keywords into content clusters

Use SERP-based clustering. If two keywords show 70%+ overlap in top-ranking URLs, they belong on the same page. Pattern-based tools miss this completely.

Tool tip: I cluster keywords with Keyword Insights.

4. Architect topic hubs

Create pillar pages for broad topics. Build cluster pages for specific subtopics. Internally link them both ways. This signals comprehensive coverage to Google.

5. Execute content gap analysis

Find every cluster where competitors rank, but you don't. Prioritize by search volume and difficulty. These are your highest-ROI opportunities.

6. Create content with information gain

Add unique value. Original research, firsthand experience, expert analysis. AI 'consensus' content doesn't tend to build authority.

7. Weave strategic internal links

Hub-and-spoke model. Every cluster links to its pillar. Every pillar links to all clusters. No page should be orphaned (left on its own).

Sites that master this see 57% faster traffic growth than those that don't (Graphite, 2024).

The question isn't whether to build topical authority.

It's whether you'll build it before your competitors do.

posts.text:
I just went on Greg Isenberg's podcast and broke down 6 proven playbooks that took bootstrapped SaaS from $0 to $300K MRR.

Real examples.
Real numbers.
Real tactics you can copy.

Here's how to get customers for your SaaS in 2026:

(PS. Watch the podcast here: https://lnkd.in/e-CjhaAz)

The companies we're reverse engineering:

- Kleo: $61K MRR
- TrustMRR: $24K MRR (in 30 days)
- Teachizy: $65K MRR
- Tally: $338K MRR
- LocalRank: $47K MRR
- Mailscale: $100K+ MRR

Playbook 1: The Waitlist Strategy

We used this for Kleo. Hit $61K MRR in 53 days.

The framework: Content ‚Üí Email ‚Üí Webinar

Create "edusales" content that subtly teases your product. Don't hard sell. Lead with value. Plug your tool in ONE bullet point.

Launch beta to your waitlist with early-bird lifetime discount.

We offered the first 500 users lifetime access for $59 (normally $99).

This creates scarcity and FOMO.

Hit $61K MRR before even launching publicly.

Stack your calendar with customer calls. Use first 500 users to iterate. Then relaunch to second cohort at a higher price.

Playbook 2: The Wave Surfer Strategy

TrustMR by Marc Lou: $24K MRR in 30 days.

Pieter Levels tweeted, complaining about fake MRR screenshots on X.

Marc shipped TrustMRR within 48 hours.

He didn't use his own audience. He piggybacked on Pieter‚Äôs virality.

Ship fast. Quit fast if it doesn't work.

Build virality into the product. TrustMRR is inherently shareable.

When you get massive attention but low intent, sell ads instead of subscriptions.

Playbook 3: Language Arbitrage Strategy

Teachizy: $65K MRR

They took Kajabi/Teachable and made it 100% French.

That's it. Same product. Different language.

SEO in other languages = marketing on easy mode. High volume. Low competition. It's what SEO in English looked like in the early 2000s.

Playbook 4: AI Search Strategy

Tally: $338K MRR

They became the #1 recommended form builder in ChatGPT.

Result: 2,000+ new users from AI search in 2025 alone.

Created comprehensive alternatives pages and "best of" articles. When people search "Typeform alternative" in ChatGPT, Tally shows up first.

Traffic from ChatGPT converts 4-5x better than Google. In some cases, 17x better.

Why? People trust ChatGPT like a friend.

Plus ChatGPT gives 2-3 recommendations vs 1,000 blue links.

The next 6 months are the biggest window to take advantage of this.

Playbook 5: Signal Search Strategy

LocalRank: $47K MRR. Made $5K MRR on day one.

They shipped ONE feature (a heat map) to test market response.

This let them validate demand before investing months into a full platform.

They launched it on YouTube and X (YouTube drove 80% of signups)

Oops, I've run out of characters.

Check out Playbook 6: High Ticket Ad Strategy (Mailscale: $100K MRR) in the comments üëá

I spent 8 hours researching these SaaS strategies so you don't have to...

Which playbook do you like best?

posts.text:
We literally live and breathe this SEO framework.

5 years ago, we watched a SaaS company burn through 6 months of content budget. 60 blog posts on topics like "what is email marketing" and "benefits of newsletters."

Their traffic skyrocketed, but their revenue flatlined.

Their entire content game was backwards.

So that's when we built our "SEO Content Pyramid" to flip it completely and start at the top.

Here's how it works:

1. Convert (Top of Pyramid)

High-intent content for people ready to buy.

A. Competitor Comparisons
‚Ü≥ "beehiiv vs Kit"
‚Ü≥ "Kit alternatives"

B. Product Reviews
‚Ü≥ "beehiiv reviews" (brand)
‚Ü≥ "Kit review" (competitor)

C. Buyer Guides
‚Ü≥ "Best newsletter platforms in 2025"
‚Ü≥ "Best newsletter tools for beginners"

D. Product Pages
‚Ü≥ "Email newsletter software"
‚Ü≥ "Newsletter platform pricing"

2. Discover (Middle of Pyramid)

Solution content for people exploring options.

A. Solve Pain Points
‚Ü≥ "How to start a newsletter"
‚Ü≥ "Newsletter best practices"

B. Case Studies
‚Ü≥ "Email marketing case studies"
‚Ü≥ "How [Brand] grew to 100k subscribers"

C. Data Studies
‚Ü≥ "Open rate benchmarks 2025"
‚Ü≥ "Email marketing statistics"

D. Templates and Tools
‚Ü≥ "Newsletter templates"
‚Ü≥ "Email subject line generator"

3. Awareness (Bottom of Pyramid)

Educational content for people learning and exploring.

A. Definitions
‚Ü≥ "What is open rate"
‚Ü≥ "Email deliverability explained"

B. Educational Guides
‚Ü≥ "How to increase email open rate"
‚Ü≥ "How to write engaging emails"

C. Industry Trends and News
‚Ü≥ "Gmail manage subscriptions feature"
‚Ü≥ "Email marketing trends 2025"

D. Ideas
‚Ü≥ "Newsletter content ideas"
‚Ü≥ "Email campaign ideas for holidays"

Start at the top with Convert content. Only move to Discover once you've covered every competitor comparison, product review, and buyer guide. Then tackle Awareness last.

This framework will 10x your SEO results.

posts.text:
How I rank businesses inside LLMs:

AI platforms handle millions of daily queries, Google now shows AI summaries on 1 in 5 searches, Google is making AI Mode the default.

This isn't just another SEO hype.

But successful AI SEO follows 7 key steps that most people completely miss.

Here‚Äôs my AI SEO playbook:

Step 1: Map your customer questions

Write down every question from your sales calls. Those same questions are being asked in ChatGPT right now.

But don't stop there. Map the follow-up questions too. LLMs love comprehensive answers.

Step 2: Create answer-focused pages

Build pages that directly answer those questions. Skip the fluff and get straight to solutions.

Step 3: Get authentic forum mentions

Make a real account on forums like Reddit. Use your real name and company. Give genuinely helpful answers in relevant threads.

Answer long-tail questions others ignore. These feed directly into LLM responses.

But don't spam. Communities spot fake accounts instantly.

Step 4: Publish YouTube videos

Target specific problems your customers face. LLMs love video citations for complex topics.

Focus on topics where written content falls short.

Step 5: Build strategic affiliate partnerships

Partner with creators who naturally mention your solutions. Authentic recommendations carry more weight than ads.

Step 6: Maximise quality citations everywhere

Get mentioned in blog posts, forums, podcasts. More citations equal more LLM visibility.

Quality beats quantity. One mention in a trusted source outperforms ten low-quality ones.

Step 7: Track your brand mentions religiously

Use a tool like Mentions to monitor when and how your brand (and each competitor) appears.

The AI revolution isn't killing SEO. It's creating new opportunities for companies willing to adapt.

The biggest opportunity?

Even early-stage companies can win immediately.

You don't need domain authority like Google. You just need to get cited and you‚Äôll start showing up.

"I don't know how to do SEO in 2025"

Start from level 1 in The ‚ÄúNew SEO‚Äù Game:

SEO isn't just Google rankings anymore.

It's now "Search Everywhere Optimization".

Reframe your ‚ÄúNew SEO‚Äù project as a game, and you'll become addicted to levelling up.

Level 1: Traditional SEO

- Audit your site for technical issues
- Research keywords and target quick wins
- Optimize on-page elements (titles, content)
- Build backlinks via guest posts and digital PR

Level 2: AI Search Optimization

- Optimize content for AI Overviews
- Structure content for AI consumption
- Create citation-worthy content for AI search
- Test how your brand appears in AI search results

Level 3: Paid Search Visibility

- Launch Google Ads for high-intent keywords
- Create YouTube Search Ads targeting competitors
- Use Microsoft Ads for Bing and AI-powered search
- Track paid visibility across all search platforms

Level 4: LLM Answer SEO

- Create comprehensive, factual content for LLMs
- Build a knowledge base for AI training data
- Establish your brand as the authority LLMs reference
- Monitor brand mentions in LLMs with Mentions.so

Level 5: Brand Authority SEO

- Get unlinked brand mentions across the web
- Feature in industry roundups and expert lists
- Build brand recognition without traditional backlinks
- Track brand mention volume and sentiment

Level 6: Community SEO

- Answer questions in relevant Reddit communities
- Participate in Quora discussions in your niche
- Engage in Slack communities and Discord servers
- Build reputation in industry forums and groups

Level 7: Parasite SEO

- Repurpose content on Medium and LinkedIn Articles
- Publish Substack newsletters to rank in Google
- Guest post on high-authority platforms/websites
- Leverage existing domain authority for quick rankings

Level 8: Platform-Specific SEO

- Optimize for Amazon search if selling products
- Focus on YouTube SEO for video content
- Master TikTok's algorithm for short-form content
- Optimize App Store listings for apps/extensions

Level 9: Topic Domination

- Own conversations across ALL channels
- Create content ecosystems to reinforce each platform
- Become the go-to expert mentioned everywhere
- Monitor and maintain authority across all channels

Completed all levels?

SEO is constantly evolving in 2025.

Stay ahead or get left behind.

PS. Need help levelling up? We'll help build and execute your ‚ÄúNew SEO‚Äù domination strategy.

posts.text:
How does AI search actually work today?

This is what happens between ask and answer:

Unlike older models that leaned on recall, GPT-5 grounds answers in live sources with a search-and-verify loop.

1. Your Question

Uses chat history and general location for relevance.

2. Decide to Search

If the model needs fresh, verifiable, or comparative info, it turns on search.

3. Plan Search

Breaks your ask into sub-queries, chooses a provider, sets recency or domain limits.

4A. Web Retrieval

Hits a search index with keywords and vectors, re-ranks for relevance, freshness, and diversity, and returns candidate URLs/snippets.

4B‚ÄìF. Where that index comes from

- Websites: Public pages and feeds
- Collect Pages: Crawlers/APIs fetch, follow robots.txt
- Clean & Split: Strip boilerplate; chunk with metadata
- Index for Search: Make embeddings; add entities/links
- Search Index: Searchable store for keyword and vector

5. Open Pages

Fetches the chosen URLs, renders HTML, follows redirects, normalizes canonicals.

6. Evidence

Pulls clean, cited snippets with dates and URLs; filters out duplicates.

7. Write Answer

Composes from the evidence; can add steps, tables, comparisons, citations.

8. Quality Check

Groundedness and policy screens; flags conflicting claims across sources.

9. Answer

Final explanation with sources and follow-ups. Clicks and re-asks feed a small feedback loop for better routing next time.

Curious to know how you show up in AI answers?

Use Mentions.

posts.text:
I‚Äôm seeing tons of misleading SEO advice for AI search.

Let‚Äôs bust 5 of the biggest myths:

1. ‚ÄúYou need to write in a special way for LLMs to understand you‚Äù

LLMs are trained on billions of examples of natural language: conversations, books, web pages, social media. They learn patterns, context, and slang the way people actually write.

That makes them robust to typos, casual grammar, and everyday phrasing. In other words: they‚Äôre built to process normal human language, not rigid SEO-style writing.

2. ‚ÄúAdding an llms.txt file will improve visibility in AI search results‚Äù

llms.txt is not a ranking factor. It‚Äôs a proposed standard for telling AI models what they can or can‚Äôt use, but most don‚Äôt even honor it.

Publishing one doesn‚Äôt boost how often you show up in AI answers, visibility comes from shaping your brand narrative across sites, communities, and trusted sources, not from a text file.

3. ‚ÄúAI will reliably use schema markup to generate answers‚Äù

Schema is intended as a hint, not a guarantee. Most LLMs don‚Äôt consistently parse schema, often ignore it when conflicting content exists, or give higher weight to context from non-schema sources.

Presence of schema does not assure inclusion in generated answers.

4. ‚ÄúLLMs just pulls from the first page of Google results‚Äù

AI answers don‚Äôt simply mirror the SERP. Yes, there‚Äôs overlap with the top 10 results, but it varies a lot:

- Perplexity: 82% overlap
- Google AI Mode: 35% overlap
- ChatGPT: 28% overlap

And beyond SERPs, 40% of AI answers come from Reddit and other community-driven sources. Meaning: ranking on page one isn‚Äôt enough, visibility in AI requires presence across forums, news, and niche sites too.

5. ‚ÄúYou need special tactics to win spots in AI Overviews‚Äù

Google has been clear that there isn‚Äôt a hidden trick. AI Overviews rely on the same fundamentals as organic search: high-quality, relevant, authoritative content.

If your pages already perform well in traditional search, they‚Äôre eligible to be surfaced in AI Overviews. What matters is clarity, expertise, and trustworthiness, not special tactics or gimmicks.

Did I miss any big myths you‚Äôve seen?

author.occupation: Helping brands get rankings and revenue from Google, LLMs, AI Overviews | CEO of Contact.so | Mentions.so | Kleo.so

posts.text:
In a few hours, we're opening Kleo 2.0.

Here‚Äôs my mindset going into this launch:

"Make it EXIST first. You can make it [really] GOOD later."

We could've waited another 30 days to make it "perfect." But perfection doesn't exist. Feedback does.

So we're shipping it today.

500 beta spots. First come, first serve. Then we close (again).

Jake Ward, Lara Acosta, Cameron Trew and I have spent months rebuilding Kleo from the ground up. Late nights. Brutal feedback. Scrapping features.

For context: The new Kleo is a writing workflow tool for LinkedIn. It helps you go from idea to published post in minutes.

This isn't a minor update.

We rewrote the entire core. It now handles everything from brainstorming ideas to writing with your knowledge to maintaining your voice.

Some early reactions:

"You actually listened"
"This is what I needed from day one"
"This changes everything for my workflow"

We're only letting 500 people in this first wave. We want to work closely with this group. Your feedback will shape what Kleo becomes for the next 100,000 users.

A few hours from now, the link is going live to the waitlist. First 500 get access. Everyone else stays on the waitlist.

I'll drop the waitlist link in the comments.

Let's build something incredible together.
